text: Susan Lyon is perhaps best known for a
role as CEO of Martha Stewart
now she's CEO of the gilt groupe an
online luxury retailer I asked her to
talk about some of the most important
leadership lessons she's learned over
the course of her career why are the
things Diane stood when I when I came to
the company was office hours it's hugely
useful you know it's usually two hours a
week where anyone can book a half hour
with me anyone in the entire company
sometimes they come you know just
because they want FaceTime with me but
usually it's because they've got
something on their minds that is
concerning them and it's my early
warning system for anything that could
grow into a problem and do you find that
people come into your office and say
Susan I want to talk to you about X and
here it is this is my concern is that is
it uncomfortable process at all or never
you know usually it takes you know maybe
fifteen or twenty minutes for them to
get to the real point and sometimes they
don't even know what I'm gonna find
interesting so it it's frequently one
line that I will hear that drives the
conversation in a different direction
very very valuable he went from being
CEO of Martha Stewart to now at the
guild group talk about that transition
and how you manage at the guild group
and maybe things that you're doing new
or differently you know I had a very
large corner office when I was at Martha
Stewart when I came to gilt it was
really clear that nobody had offices and
I hadn't been in a newsroom setup just
cubicles and god knows how long
and I will say the first week that I was
there you know sitting at my workstation
surrounded by people I thought oh my god
I'm not sure I can do this but very
quickly I thought this is so great
I am very accessible I would never have
an office again you had mentioned to me
that Gilt Groupe is growing very quickly
you're doing a lot of hiring talk about
how you hire being able to recruit is
critically important and being able to
recruit the right people you know it's a
it's an art I think and I have my
failure rate like everybody else but
what what I try to do is to make sure
that I don't let someone run away with
the interview and essentially just sell
me and there are questions that that are
always useful to have dig in and see
whether this is a person who would fit
in you mentioned fitting in what what
are the qualities you're looking for and
what are some of the the key phrases
that might wig your ear yep I in our
company and I think any company being
able to work effectively as part of a
team is critically important so you know
anybody who says I all the time instead
of we and anybody who is uncomfortable
talking about their failures or things
they think they could have done better
what qualities are you looking for more
now than you used to
in hires you know I used to I used to
look for the most talented person the
person who was a superstar and I still
obviously look for really talented
people but they have got to be able to
work within a company
and it's it's key to your success at a
company to be able to get people who are
not direct reports to work with you give
you time and to want you to succeed and
so people who have strong peer
relationships are more and more
important to me and what is your advice
for business school deans if you had an
auditorium full of them you were at the
lectern what would you suggest they
teach more of or less of in their
curriculum you know I think this this
idea of managing across companies
instead of just managing down and
managing up is critically important I
think there's not enough real attention
paid to to peer relationships and how to
build them and it is there's no question
that your success as you are rising
within a company will depend on on how
often and how well you are able to
access the resources that are not
directly under your control
you
